chunks.original_text: 忽然而醒，德玄乃苏。 开目起来，见家春围榻泣之。 家眷曰：你今死三日。 德玄云：有此圣事。 遂拾其家，缘入景灵观出家作道士，唯修清净之教。 后十二年，有紫云从空而来。 见碧衣童子引仙鹤一双，降於庭前，而谓德玄曰：请上鹤背，跨而去。 遂德玄跃鹤背上，冉冉而升天。 其异香一月不散。 乃留诗一首云：人事纷纷百万端，蝇名蜗利不堪看。 争如悟此清中静，功满升为天上官。 论曰：动静相磨，阴阳相感，而万物相生。 悟此道者升为天官。 窦德玄知之矣。 降本流末，而生万物。 本者元炁。 道生一，一者，元气为本也。 末者，万物也。 道生一，一生二，二生三，三生万物。 大道之本。 此句太上再序清浊、动静之理，言道生元炁，元炁降而本流，本流则万物生，故为末。 此为降本流末，而生万物也。 文中子曰：统元炁者天也，总元炁者地也。 无形生养元炁，元炁无形，生养万物。 故曰降本流末而生万物。 元炁既降，流行为末。 《易》曰，元炁降者，在天成象，在地成形，变化显见矣。 在天成象，为悬象，日月星辰也。 在地成形，谓山川草木也。 故曰降本流末而生万物。 庄子曰：至阳天也，至阴地也。 而肃肃之炁，至於心火，乃水火既济，而养万神。 故曰降本流末而生万物。 或曰：看此真经，还有验乎？ 答曰：看此真经，须要救物度生。 昔有唐时防州宋知玄，为青州司士参军。 参军到彼，人言参军之宅大凶，有鬼怪妖异，住者十死六七。 知玄自来好道，而心正直，兼少年好诵《太上老君清静真经》，深达其义，又能体而行之。 遂不信：吾安居，何信此事乎。 坚住其宅，乃修《吕真人诗》一首：金丹一粒定长生，须得真铅炼甲庚。 火取南方赤凤髓，水求北海黑龟精。 鼎追四季中央土，药遣三元八卦行。 斋戒与功成九转，少持清静鬼神惊。 知玄乃危坐，行其火轮罩体，红光满室，默念《清净》之经。 至二更已来，忽见一妇人披发，而血污满面，立于前。 知玄曰：尔乃何人也？ 妇人曰：我是衔冤之鬼也。 其人拜而哭曰：与妾为力。 今日遇有道之士，而得诉事。 妾本十年前，乃刘司士之妻也。 夫奉命为使外国而不归，其弟乃逼妾私通。 推而不从，因此被杀。 以毡裹其尸于堂西北角，溷厕之中，不胜秽积。 人来多欲陈告，人人怯惧，无其道气，见妾之形，心惧而死者多矣。 公持此经，功德至大，仁慈。 愿为悯之。
chunks.translated_text:
Suddenly, Dexuan awoke as if from a dream. Opening his eyes, he saw his family weeping around his bed. His kin said, "You have been dead for three days." Dexuan replied, "There was such holy business." Thereafter, he put his household in order, entered Jingling Abbey, and became a Daoist, devoting himself solely to the teachings of purity and stillness. Twelve years later, a purple cloud descended from the sky. A jade-clad youth led a pair of cranes before the courtyard and said to Dexuan, "Please mount the crane’s back and depart." Dexuan leapt onto the crane, ascending slowly into the heavens. A rare fragrance lingered for a month. He left behind a poem:

A hundred thousand threads of worldly affairs,
The fly’s fame, the snail’s gain—unworthy of sight.
How much better to awaken to this purity and stillness,
When merit is full, ascend as an official of heaven.

The commentary states: Movement and stillness grind against each other, yin and yang interact, and thus the myriad things are born. Those who comprehend this Dao ascend as celestial officials. Dou Dexuan understood this. The root flows into the branches, giving rise to the myriad things. The root is primordial *qi*. The Dao gives birth to the One; the One is the primordial *qi* as the root. The branches are the myriad things. The Dao gives birth to the One, the One to the Two, the Two to the Three, and the Three to the myriad things. This is the root of the Great Dao.

This passage from the Supreme Lord Lao once more expounds the principles of purity and turbidity, movement and stillness: the Dao gives birth to primordial *qi*, primordial *qi* descends as the root and flows forth, and from this flow the myriad things are born—thus, the branches. This is the descent of the root and the flow of the branches, giving rise to the myriad things.

Master Wenzi said: "Heaven governs primordial *qi*, Earth encompasses primordial *qi*. The formless nurtures primordial *qi*, and primordial *qi*, though formless, nurtures the myriad things." Thus, it is said: the root descends and flows into the branches, giving rise to the myriad things. Once primordial *qi* descends, it flows forth as the branches.

The *Book of Changes* states: "When primordial *qi* descends, in heaven it forms images, on earth it takes shape—transformation and manifestation are evident." In heaven, it forms images: the suspended images of the sun, moon, and stars. On earth, it takes shape: the mountains, rivers, grasses, and trees. Thus, it is said: the root descends and flows into the branches, giving rise to the myriad things.

Zhuangzi said: "The utmost yang is Heaven, the utmost yin is Earth. The reverent *qi* reaches the heart’s fire, and with water and fire in harmony, the myriad spirits are nurtured." Thus, it is said: the root descends and flows into the branches, giving rise to the myriad things.

Someone asked: "Is there proof in studying this true scripture?"
The answer: "To study this true scripture, one must save beings and deliver lives. In the Tang dynasty, there was Song Zhixuan of Fangzhou, who served as Assistant Officer in Qizhou. When he arrived, people said his residence was inauspicious, haunted by ghosts and malevolent spirits—of those who lived there, six or seven out of ten died. Zhixuan, who had always loved the Dao, was upright in heart and, from his youth, had recited the *Scripture of the Supreme Lord Lao on Purity and Stillness*. He deeply understood its meaning and embodied its practice. Thus, he refused to believe: 'How could I not dwell in peace? Why heed such talk?' He resolutely took up residence in the house and composed a poem by Master Lü:

A single grain of golden elixir ensures long life,
True lead must refine the cyclical stems.
Fire draws the crimson phoenix’s marrow from the south,
Water seeks the black turtle’s essence from the northern sea.
The crucible follows the earth at the center of the four seasons,
The medicine follows the three origins and eight trigrams.
With fasting and merit complete in nine revolutions,
Even ghosts and spirits tremble at purity and stillness.

Zhixuan sat solemnly, circulating the fire-wheel to envelop his body. Red light filled the room as he silently recited the *Scripture of Purity and Stillness*. Around the second watch, a woman with disheveled hair and a bloodstained face suddenly appeared before him. Zhixuan asked, 'Who are you?' The woman replied, 'I am a ghost with a grievance.' She bowed and wept, saying, 'I beg for your help. Today, I have encountered a man of the Dao and may finally voice my plight. Ten years ago, I was the wife of Liu, an Officer of Affairs. My husband was sent on a mission abroad and never returned. His younger brother forced himself upon me. When I resisted, he killed me, wrapped my body in felt, and hid it in the northwest corner of the hall, beneath the privy, where filth accumulated. Many have wished to report this, but all feared my form. Lacking the *qi* of the Dao, they died of terror upon seeing me. Your recitation of this scripture carries great merit and kindness. I beg your compassion.'"

chunks.original_text: 知玄曰：吾初官，新上任三日，当救汝。 汝且灭。 妇人遂灭。 后三日满，使人於溷厕掘之其尺，不及。 知玄是夜依前危坐，焚香诵此经。 未及二鼓，其妇人复现。 知玄曰：我令人求汝之尸，未获，何也？ 妇人曰：求之者，向北不及二尺，即妾尸也。 明旦求之，以终其惠也。 妇人乃灭。 明旦使人于北求之，果获旧毡一片，而裹白骨一副。 知玄再为诵《清净经》，以衣一袭，而选一吉地葬之。 是夜，其妇洁衣净面，而再拜灯下。 知玄曰：汝身既为人杀之，何以不报？ 答曰：前人在江州为司录之官，其人自小能诵《太上老君说常清静经》，数年冥司陈告，终取不得。 知玄曰：我与告彼官，使彼官修斋作醮，书篆黄箓白简，汝可生天。 肯解此冤乎？ 妇人再拜曰：深相感也。 道罢，其妇人遂灭。 知玄来入假状于官，因得其假。 遂乃裹粮，便马径至江州，乃见刘司录。 既见，乃以其事告曰：汝为司录，孰为此事？ 闻君唯持《太上老君清静经》，是有道心也，而行此事。 岂不明有官法处之，暗有鬼神沬之。 若不改过，冤业如何？

Zhixuan said, "When I first took office, I had been in my post for only three days—I shall save you then. Now, disappear for the time being." The woman vanished.

Three days later, when the time had elapsed, he sent men to dig in the privy, but they fell short by a foot. That night, Zhixuan once more sat upright as before, burning incense and reciting the scripture. Before the second watch had ended, the woman reappeared.

Zhixuan asked, "I sent men to search for your remains, yet they were not found. Why is this?"

The woman replied, "Had they dug two feet farther north, they would have found my body. Search there at dawn to fulfill your kindness."

The woman then vanished. The next morning, men were sent to dig northward, and indeed, they uncovered an old felt wrapping containing a set of white bones. Zhixuan recited the *Scripture of Purity* once more, provided a set of clothing, and chose an auspicious site to bury her.

That night, the woman appeared again, her garments clean and her face washed. She bowed twice before the lamp.

Zhixuan asked, "Since you were killed by another, why have you not sought retribution?"

She answered, "The man was once a Registrar in Jiangzhou. From childhood, he had recited the *Laozi’s Scripture on Constant Purity and Stillness*. For years, I petitioned the underworld authorities, but to no avail."

Zhixuan said, "I shall report to that official, urging him to perform a fast and offer a *jiao* ritual, inscribing talismans on yellow registers and white petitions. Then you may ascend to heaven. Will you release this grievance?"

The woman bowed twice and said, "I am deeply grateful."

As the Dao was spoken, the woman vanished.

Zhixuan then submitted a leave request to his superior and obtained permission. He packed provisions, mounted his horse, and traveled directly to Jiangzhou, where he met the Registrar Liu.

Upon meeting him, Zhixuan recounted the matter and asked, "As a Registrar, who could have committed such a deed? I have heard you recite the *Scripture of the Supreme Lord Lao on Purity and Stillness*—this shows a heart attuned to the Dao. Yet you have done this. Do you not know that while the law of officials punishes openly, the unseen spirits of ghosts and gods also exact justice? If you do not repent, how will you escape the karmic burden of this grievance?"

chunks.original_text: 刘司录闻之，大惊曰：谢公远来，蒙为纷解，安敢违命。 乃整其家财，作黄箓大醮七日七夜，请道一百余人，及印《清静经》一万本散施。 是日午时，有一妇人，年可三十，牵一宝马，驼经万卷，乃曰：吾乘此经醮力，奉太上老君勑，使我入朱陵官炼其真神，当为南宫列仙。 吾在世长年，宋参军亦为列仙。 道罢，冉冉升空而去。 知玄与刘司录号为道友，求奉真教。 知玄却回防州，至家，有青鸾下于庭。 知玄乃焚香，遂青鸾冉冉而亦南去。 留下一诗云：来生清净悟真经，拔罪扶危出罪刑。 今日乘斯功德力，朱陵官裹炼神形。 论曰：修真之士，乘斯功德，体道行功； 识降本流末之义，知万物化生之因； 扶危拔困，救厄解冤。 有此清净，行此慈悲，岂不为南官列仙也。 南宫列仙之位，宋知玄得之。 此者能悟降本流末而生万物也。 清者浊之源，动者静之基#1。 清者，一炁也； 浊者，万物也。 动者，神也； 静者，形也。 太上言道以一气为万物之祖，祖为源也。 人神以一形为舍，故合为基本也。 形不得神不能动，神不得形不能存。 神为主人，形为舍基此二句大底言道炁为万物之本，分其清静。 清者元气，浊者万物之形也。 人能以神动保固其形，故为万物之基源。 故云清者浊之源，动者静之基。 白云翁曰：不浊无以见其清，不清无以见其浊。 无一炁而不能生万物，无万物不能分一气。 故曰清者浊之源，动者静之基。 文中子曰：至清则见浊，此清者浊之源； 至动则思静，此动者静之基也。 修真之士，以一气养神，故清； 以五味养腹，故浊。 则神要动而顺，形以静而安形，此乃清浊动静之道也。 此经还有验也。 答曰：昔唐人袁通，天水人。 自幼年好道，专诵《太上老君清静经》，日诵七七遍。 年至二十，被禄山驱为军战，忽失阵而败。 袁通乃走，不知来路，遂於山丛之闲不得食，其困不能兴，唯诵此《清净经》，无力可诵以待死。 忽有一碧衣童子，持一盂饭来与食之。 袁通食之，其香味不可名状。 食其满足矣，其童子曰：真人以清气养其清腹，凡人以外物养其浊腹； 真人以气运神而安其静，凡人以乱神败精而乐其形。 汝自幼好道而能坚，至念《太上老君清静之经》，已有道果，太上而使赠也，从兹以充餐，用神为道，更不食矣。 乃今黑簿落名，朱陵排号，清净之道更不虚矣。 道罢，忽然不见。 袁通从此不食，乃得六通之慧。 至於宋哲宗之朝犹在。 唐玄宗时事，五百年问，面若三十岁许。 常游洛汭之间，唯只念《清净》之经，人不见其饮食。 人呼之清净先生。 若人有患，不唯远近之疾，以手摩娑，人皆无有不者。 后又被人呼摸着效。 后至汴京门外，高声曰：你待乱，我不乱； 你待浊，我不浊。 你东西，安能活？
chunks.translated_text:
Upon hearing this, Registrar Liu was greatly startled and said, "I thank you, sir, for coming so far to resolve this entanglement. How dare I defy your counsel?" He then gathered his family's wealth and held a grand *Huanglu* Offering for seven days and seven nights, inviting over a hundred Daoists to participate. He also printed ten thousand copies of the *Scripture of the Supreme Lord Lao on Purity and Stillness* to distribute as alms.

At noon that day, a woman of about thirty appeared, leading a treasure horse laden with ten thousand scrolls of scriptures. She said, "By the power of this scripture and offering, I have received the decree of the Supreme Lord Lao to enter the Vermilion Palace and refine my true spirit, ascending as an Immortal of the Southern Palace. In my long life in the world, Military Advisor Song also became an Immortal of the Southern Palace." Having spoken, she slowly rose into the sky and departed.

Zhixuan and Registrar Liu then pledged themselves as fellow Daoists, vowing to uphold the true teachings. Zhixuan returned to Fangzhou, and upon reaching home, a green phoenix descended into his courtyard. He burned incense, and the green phoenix slowly drifted southward, leaving behind a poem:

*In past lives, pure and awakened to the true scripture,*
*Lifting sins and aiding the imperiled from punishment.*
*Today, by this merit’s power,*
*In the Vermilion Palace, spirit and form refine.*

It is said: The adept who cultivates the true, riding this merit, embodies the Dao and performs its works—understanding the principle of descending from root to branch, knowing the causes of the myriad things’ transformation; aiding the endangered, rescuing the distressed, and resolving grievances. With such purity and compassion, how could one not become an Immortal of the Southern Palace? The rank of Immortal of the Southern Palace was attained by Song Zhixuan, for he comprehended the descent from root to branch in the generation of the myriad things.

The pure is the source of the turbid; movement is the foundation of stillness. The pure is the primordial *qi*; the turbid is the myriad things. Movement is spirit; stillness is form. The Supreme Lord speaks of the Dao, taking the singular *qi* as the ancestor of the myriad things—for the ancestor is the source. The human spirit takes the singular form as its abode, thus uniting as the fundamental basis. Without spirit, form cannot move; without form, spirit cannot endure. Spirit is the master; form is the abode. These two lines broadly speak of the Dao’s *qi* as the root of the myriad things, distinguishing purity and stillness. The pure is the primordial *qi*; the turbid is the form of the myriad things. If one can move with spirit while preserving and securing form, one becomes the foundation and source of the myriad things. Thus it is said: the pure is the source of the turbid; movement is the foundation of stillness.

The Old Man of White Clouds said: Without turbidity, purity cannot be perceived; without purity, turbidity cannot be perceived. Without the singular *qi*, the myriad things cannot be born; without the myriad things, the singular *qi* cannot be divided. Thus it is said: the pure is the source of the turbid; movement is the foundation of stillness.

Master Wen said: In utmost purity, turbidity is seen—this is the pure as the source of the turbid. In utmost movement, stillness is contemplated—this is movement as the foundation of stillness. The adept who cultivates the true nurtures spirit with the singular *qi*, hence purity; nurtures the belly with the five flavors, hence turbidity. Thus spirit must move in accord, while form rests in stillness—this is the Dao of purity and turbidity, movement and stillness.

This scripture has further verification. It is said: In the Tang dynasty, there was a man named Yuan Tong from Tianshui. From childhood, he loved the Dao and devoted himself to reciting the *Scripture of the Supreme Lord Lao on Purity and Stillness*, chanting it forty-nine times daily. At the age of twenty, he was conscripted by An Lushan’s army and suddenly lost in battle. Yuan Tong fled, unaware of his path, and in the mountain thickets, unable to find food, he grew so weak he could not rise. He continued reciting the *Scripture of Purity and Stillness*, though without strength, awaiting death.

Suddenly, a youth in green robes appeared, holding a bowl of rice, and offered it to him. Yuan Tong ate, and its fragrance and flavor were beyond description. After eating his fill, the youth said, "The perfected nurture their pure bellies with pure *qi*; ordinary people nurture their turbid bellies with external things. The perfected circulate *qi* to harmonize spirit and settle stillness; ordinary people scatter spirit and deplete essence to delight in form. From childhood, you have loved the Dao and remained steadfast, reciting the *Scripture of the Supreme Lord Lao on Purity and Stillness*—you have already borne the fruit of the Dao. The Supreme Lord has sent me to bestow this upon you. From now on, let this sustain you. Use spirit for the Dao, and you will no longer need to eat. Today, your name has been stricken from the Black Register and arranged in the Vermilion Palace. The Dao of purity and stillness is not in vain."

Having spoken, the youth vanished. From then on, Yuan Tong no longer ate and attained the wisdom of the six penetrations. He lived until the reign of Emperor Zhezong of the Song, though the events occurred in the time of Emperor Xuanzong of the Tang—five hundred years passed, yet his face remained as that of a man of thirty. He often wandered between the Luo and Ru rivers, reciting only the *Scripture of Purity and Stillness*, and no one ever saw him eat. People called him the Master of Purity and Stillness. If someone suffered illness, no matter how distant, he would stroke them with his hand, and there was none who did not recover. Later, people imitated his touch.

Once, outside the gates of Bianjing, he cried out loudly: "You seek chaos—I do not. You seek turbidity—I do not. You rush about—how can you live?"

where he met the Registrar Liu.

Upon meeting him, Zhixuan recounted the matter and asked, "As a Registrar, who could have committed such a deed? I have heard you recite the *Scripture of the Supreme Lord Lao on Purity and Stillness*—this shows a heart attuned to the Dao. Yet you have done this. Do you not know that while the law of officials punishes openly, the unseen spirits of ghosts and gods also exact justice? If you do not repent, how will you escape the karmic burden of this grievance?"

chunks.original_text: 从得道，五百年，斩却邪魔神快乐。 乘云驾鹤背，朝玉帝天官，永住逍遥阁。 道毕，自有仙鹤从天而飞下。 先生急上鹤背，冉冉乘云而去。 人皆俯仰而瞻之。 从空坠下纸一张，其上写曰：清净道生。 道生数十律。 论曰：大道者，视之不见，听之不闻，而天下莫能知，莫能行。 虽不知不见，修之者实有道焉。 太上曰：吾言甚易知，甚易行。 故道降而为元气，清而为浊之源； 动而为静之基。 一清一浊，而通大道。 故袁通能至诚，悟《太上清静经》，终为上升而列仙。 宜乎哉。 人能常清静，天地悉皆归。 天地者，乃大道之子孙也； 人物者，大道之苗裔也。 太上言人能禀大道一之祖气，使身心之虚灵，神气之清静，如此能体其大道也，与天地合德。 故天地自然而从顺，悉皆归依也。 故曰人能常清静，天地悉皆归。 行清静之教者。 《易》云：与天地相似，故不违言。 修真之士亦要清静无为，体大道真常之教，穷万物之性，能知鬼神。 是以天地相似，所为所作，故不违於天地，悉皆归顺矣。 故曰人能常清静，天地悉皆归。 文中子曰：能清静者，与太极同德，与天地同邻，与神道并行。 能为此者，天地尽皆归也。 如此者，有验乎？
chunks.translated_text:
Since attaining the Dao, five hundred years have passed—he severed the demonic and rejoiced in the divine. Riding clouds and mounting cranes, he ascended to the Jade Emperor’s celestial palace, dwelling forever in the Pavilion of Carefree Roaming.

As the recitation ended, a crane descended from the heavens. The Master swiftly mounted its back, rising gently upon the clouds. All below gazed upward in awe. From the sky fluttered a sheet of paper, inscribed with the words: *"The Dao gives birth to purity."*

The *Dao-Giving Birth* comprises dozens of precepts.

The treatise states: The Great Dao cannot be seen, cannot be heard, yet none under heaven know it, none practice it. Though unseen and unknown, those who cultivate it truly possess the Dao.

The Most High said: My words are easily understood, easily practiced. Thus, the Dao descends to become primordial qi, the source of purity and turbidity, the foundation of movement and stillness. Through the interplay of purity and turbidity, the Great Dao is realized. Therefore, Yuan Tong, through utmost sincerity, awakened to the *Scripture of the Most High’s Purity and Stillness* and ultimately ascended to join the immortals. How fitting indeed!

If one can constantly abide in purity and stillness, heaven and earth will wholly return. Heaven and earth are the descendants of the Great Dao; humanity and all beings are its offspring. The Most High teaches that if one can receive the ancestral qi of the Great Dao, rendering body and mind empty and numinous, spirit and qi pure and still—thus embodying the Great Dao—one unites in virtue with heaven and earth. Therefore, heaven and earth naturally follow and submit, wholly returning in devotion.

Thus it is said: If one can constantly abide in purity and stillness, heaven and earth will wholly return.

Those who practice the teachings of purity and stillness—*The Book of Changes* states: *"Resembling heaven and earth, thus nothing is contrary."* The adept of cultivation must also embrace purity, stillness, and non-action, embodying the true and constant teachings of the Great Dao, fathoming the nature of all things, and knowing the ways of ghosts and spirits. Thus, resembling heaven and earth, all their actions and deeds will not contravene them, and all will return in submission.

Thus it is said: If one can constantly abide in purity and stillness, heaven and earth will wholly return.

Master Wenzi said: Those who can abide in purity and stillness share virtue with the Supreme Ultimate, dwell alongside heaven and earth, and walk in step with the divine Dao. Those who achieve this will see heaven and earth wholly return. Is there evidence of this?

chunks.original_text: 答曰：昔唐庆历中有韩侍郎坐运州，有女年二十六岁，适左司员外郎王珪。 珪乃上官，其妻韩氏有妊娠，在父母家。 至日早离夜至三鼓已来，於西北角有其声。 左右侍婢皆睡，唯小娘子韩氏不睡，见一将军披戎衣，执金钗，乃曰：吾晋朝韦将军，於此居数百年，尔敢於此处作产居，血腥之气触吾。 若三日不移，杀汝。 其记之。 韩氏曰：愿移之。 遂灭。 达旦，令侍婢报知韩侍郎。 侍郎曰：妇人真气虚弱，乃胡见之。 安有此乎？ 不肯移之，唯添侍婢相伴。
chunks.translated_text: The answer states: During the Qingli era of the Tang dynasty, there was a Han, Vice Director of the Department of State Affairs, who was exiled to Yunzhou. He had a daughter, twenty-six years of age, married to Wang Gui, Vice Director of the Left Secretariat. As Wang was her superior, his wife, née Han, remained in her parents’ home during her pregnancy. One night, around the third watch, a sound arose from the northwest corner. All the maidservants were asleep, but the young mistress, née Han, remained awake. She saw a general clad in armor, holding a golden hairpin, who declared: “I am General Wei of the Jin dynasty. I have dwelled here for several hundred years. How dare you give birth in this place? The stench of blood and filth offends me. If you do not move within three days, I will kill you.” Take heed of this. Han replied: “I will move.” Then he vanished. At daybreak, she instructed her maidservants to report the matter to Vice Director Han. He said: “A woman’s *qi* is depleted and weak—how could she truly see such a thing? How could this be? He refused to move her and merely added more maidservants to keep her company.

chunks.original_text: 又至三更已来，其将军复现，侍婢皆见之，惊而走。 其将军乃叱之曰：吾道与汝，何不移之？ 来日不移，叉杀汝矣。 韩氏曰：告将军息怒，来日叉移。 其将军不见。 达旦，侍婢乃以小娘子之言哀告韩君，韩君曰：产妇未满七日，安敢移动？ 妇人血气虚而胡见乱言。 答曰：侍婢亦见。 韩君曰：妇人之辈皆信邪。 坚不从之。 至夜，其韦将军又现曰：吾三次语汝，汝、终不肯移其宅。 将军见不移，怒从心起，以其钗于韩氏心上，其一钗，韩氏只叫一声，遂殒。 其父执一剑而径至。 其父哀恸不已，父母甚慈，泣之，以飞书报其夫。 夫闻之，大恸，而不顾差使，而归至寺庄镇西十里，见一妇人遥远而来，其近，乃认是妻也。 王珪忽然下马问妻曰：何由到此也？ 其从皆见。 妻曰：妾为晋朝韦将军所杀也。 今日此屈无由申诉。 尔为大丈夫，不能避一妻子乎？ 遂哭。 珪乃大恸，欲近前行。 妻曰：人鬼异路，不可近妾。 我闻此镇有田先生，自小念《太上老君清静经》，行此之清静无为者也。 此能剪诚鬼神，有通天之德。 故曰人能常清静，天地悉皆归。 斯其以报妾之冤。 其先生在此镇。 珪谒先生，具以前事实告，先生然：吾为汝上祷玄穹，下达后土，救汝之妻。 遂引王珪至於别室中。 田先生一鼓已来，披朝服，执玉珪，把香一炉，合目跪之，点灯七盏，念咒启祷。 忽然室中有一天丁力士曰：奉天之勑，入于幽府。 会其力士放下勑，忽然不见。 先生曰：我今奉天帝之勑，与汝同往地府，令捉韦将军。 先生取净席一领，使王珪辟於席上，迷而不省。 先生於傍坐出神，引王珪神，二神相引出门。 乃行数里，见一大城。 天色昏暗，左右铁衣兵吏皆执戈戟，见先生，尽皆倒戈唱偌。 既入其门有朱衣史急通报，又数十人皆见先生，亦然仰启，只闻言：田真人至。 俄顷有绿衣童子，皆执旌节，迎一人，衣龙衮服，戴远游冠，执寒玉珪，导之曰：乃酆都大帝。 见田真人，相揖动问毕，使真人前行，让礼如几世。 鬼使问王珪曰：尔乃何人也？ 珪曰：我乃田真人从侍也。 鬼使更不问。 既上其殿，真人与帝对坐，先生展劲现帝视之，王珪等一齐贺勑。 王珪阶下立不多时，碧衣童子传曰：游奕将速於阴司，捉取晋朝阴鬼韦将军去。 有一人黄金锁子甲，手执大剑，应偌，俄顷问报日：捉到阴鬼韦将军。 王曰：擒来。 见数人申衣兵史，传一人头至阶前曰：汝数年阴鬼。 汝在世之时，杀害生灵太多，更害平人。 韦将军曰：某数次祷他不肯移之，某一时之怒杀之。 念某晋朝勋官。 帝曰：阴鬼尚敢杀害生灵，何言汝有功勋？ 可次铁杖三百，配北阴山千年而放。 左右捽缚付地，背上央铁杖三百，号叫之声，不能忍之。 决毕，有一吏曰：奉勑押至阴山。 王问韩氏游处。 左右曰：如何在此，押过来于束廊下，乃韩氏，软拜於王，王问左右：如何？ 左右曰：其舍以坏，可令借身托生。 判官乃检簿，韩氏合寿六十六岁。 更有四十年寿。 即目青州王官人女寿娘，合年二十六岁命终，可令韩氏投尸於寿娘还魂，遂准奉行。 王请先生离，王珪亦随之未〔离〕，忽然而觉。 先生曰：官人将谈此是秘。
chunks.translated_text:
Once more, as the third watch approached, the general reappeared. All the maidservants saw him and fled in terror. The general rebuked them, saying: “I have spoken to you of the Dao—why have you not moved her? If she remains here by tomorrow, I will kill her.” Han replied: “I beg you, General, calm your anger. I will move her tomorrow.” Then the general vanished.

At daybreak, the maidservants tearfully reported the young mistress’s words to Vice Director Han. He said: “A woman in childbirth cannot be moved before seven days have passed—how could she dare? Her *qi* and blood are depleted, and she raves in delirium.” They answered: “The maidservants saw him as well.” Han replied: “Women are all prone to believing in such omens.” He firmly refused to comply.

That night, General Wei appeared once more and said: “I have warned you three times, yet you still refuse to move her.” Seeing that she had not been moved, his anger flared. He struck Han with his hairpin, piercing her heart. With a single cry, she perished. Her father, brandishing a sword, rushed in. Overcome with grief, her parents wept bitterly and sent an urgent letter to her husband.

Upon receiving the news, her husband, Wang Gui, was stricken with sorrow. Disregarding his official duties, he returned home. Ten *li* west of Sizhuang Town, he saw a woman approaching from afar. As she drew near, he recognized her as his wife. Dismounting at once, he asked: “How have you come to be here?” All his attendants saw her as well. She replied: “I was killed by General Wei of the Jin dynasty. My grievance remains unaddressed. As a man of stature, can you not avenge your wife?” She wept. Wang Gui, overcome with grief, stepped forward, but she said: “The paths of the living and the dead diverge—do not come near me. I have heard that in this town there is a Master Tian, who from childhood has recited the *Classic of the Dao and Its Virtue in Supreme Purity* and practiced the Way of quiescence and non-action. He possesses the power to subdue spirits and the virtue to commune with Heaven. As the text says: ‘If one can abide in constant purity, Heaven and Earth will all return to them.’ Seek him to redress my wrong.” She told him where to find the master.

Wang Gui visited Master Tian and recounted the events in full. The master replied: “I shall intercede for you above with the Mysterious Heavens and below with the Earth Deity to save your wife.” He then led Wang Gui into a separate chamber. As the first watch began, Master Tian donned his court robes, took up a jade tablet, and held a censer of incense. Closing his eyes, he knelt and lit seven lamps, chanting an incantation to commence his prayer.

Suddenly, a celestial warrior appeared in the chamber and declared: “By decree of Heaven, I descend into the netherworld.” The warrior presented the edict, then vanished. The master said: “I now bear the Emperor of Heaven’s decree. We shall go together to the underworld to seize General Wei.” He took a clean mat and had Wang Gui lie upon it, whereupon he fell into a stupor. The master sat beside him, projecting his spirit, and guided Wang Gui’s spirit out the door.

After traveling several *li*, they saw a great city. The sky was dim, and armored soldiers on either side wielded halberds. Upon seeing the master, they all lowered their weapons and bowed in reverence. Entering the gate, a crimson-robed scribe hastily announced their arrival. Dozens of attendants, upon seeing the master, likewise prostrated themselves, crying out: “The Perfected Master Tian has arrived!”

Moments later, green-clad youths bearing banners approached, leading a figure clad in dragon robes, wearing a *yuanyou* crown, and holding a jade tablet. They announced: “This is the Great Emperor of Fengdu.” Upon seeing the Perfected Master Tian, the emperor exchanged courtesies and invited him to proceed first, showing him the utmost deference as if they were old acquaintances.

A ghostly attendant asked Wang Gui: “Who are you?” He replied: “I am an attendant of the Perfected Master Tian.” The attendant asked no further questions. Ascending the hall, the master and the emperor sat facing each other. The master presented the decree for the emperor’s inspection, and Wang Gui, along with the others, paid their respects.

Before long, a blue-robed youth announced: “The Patrol General is to swiftly apprehend the yin ghost General Wei of the Jin dynasty in the netherworld.” A warrior clad in golden chainmail, wielding a great sword, responded to the summons. Soon after, he reported: “The yin ghost General Wei has been captured.” Wang Gui said: “Bring him forth.”

Several black-robed officials dragged a man before the steps. The emperor said: “You, a yin ghost for years, killed countless living beings in your time and even harmed an innocent woman.” General Wei replied: “I warned her repeatedly, but she refused to move. In a moment of anger, I killed her. Consider my meritorious service in the Jin dynasty.” The emperor said: “Even as a yin ghost, you dare kill the living—what merit do you claim? You shall receive three hundred strokes of the iron rod and be exiled to the Northern Yin Mountain for a thousand years.” The attendants bound him and threw him to the ground, striking his back three hundred times. His cries of agony were unbearable to hear.

After the punishment, an official said: “By decree, he is to be sent to Yin Mountain.” Wang Gui asked about Han’s whereabouts. The attendants replied: “She is here—bring her forward.” They led her from the side corridor. Han knelt weakly before Wang Gui. He asked: “What is to be done?” The attendants said: “Her dwelling has been destroyed. She may borrow a body to be reborn.” The judge consulted the register and found that Han was fated to live sixty-six years, with forty years remaining. At present, a girl named Shouniang, daughter of a Wang family in Qingzhou, was due to die at twenty-six. They ordered Han to enter Shouniang’s body and revive, and the decree was carried out.

Wang Gui begged the master to depart, and he followed, still in a daze. Suddenly, he awoke. The master said: “Sir, this matter must remain secret.”

chunks.original_text: 王珪重重拜之〔问〕，先生曰：何直游至此也？ ，先生曰：我能持诵《太上老君清静真经》，能依此行之，所以与天地合其德。 人能常清静，天地悉皆归。 尔到家，速於青州王官人家认取汝妻。 王珪辞先生而去。 在路速到运州，其妻韩氏已殡矣。 径往青州王官人家，认其妻子。 王官人女寿娘死经三日，再活，却言：我是韩侍郎女，现今我父为运州知州。 说其所以，未罢，王珪至入王官人宅，见寿娘，便言：王郎来也。 其声音全不似寿娘往日声音也。 王珪曰：寿娘只是韩氏声音也。 具说其辞因，王官人乃入运州，见其父母，与向日女之音无异。 二人猛悟大道，而尽其家财，雕造印经十万余巷，散施四方，作罗天大醮而谢天地。 毕，其王珪与妻再往寺庄镇拜谢田先生。 到彼谢毕，先生曰：汝可与妻同修。 王珪依言，休官不任。 王珪挂冠裳，作道士，居长安福德观； 韩氏作女冠，居玉京观，各寿一百二十岁而损。 论曰：寂然不动，感而遂通，清净无为。 田先生遵太上之经，行天之法，上感穹苍，下通后土，使天降劝北帝评冤，可谓人能常清静，天地悉皆归。 夫人神好清而心扰之，人心好静而欲牵之。 夫人之生也，本乃神清心静，及其长也，为情欲所牵如此者，欲生也。 故欲字从谷、从欠，谷者无漏之称，欠者不足之号。 神有所爱为之情，心有所欲为之贪。 亢仓子曰：水性本清而不得清，为土浑之； 人性本静而不得静，为事汨之。 汨者，乱也。 太上言此二品，夫人神本好清静而不得清静者，为心不能体清静之道，心有爱恋之情，故扰乱之，心不能得清静矣。 夫人神好清而心扰之。 心元本好清静，而所以不得清静者，为心中有好欲之贪而牵引之。 故曰人心好静而欲牵之。 文中子曰：靡者常乐无求，贪者常忧不足。 爢者常乐无求则神好清，心好静； 贪者常忧则不足，心扰之，欲牵之。 白云翁曰：欲者，贪爱之源，奢淫之本。 若人能禀此清净之道，神必清，神清则心不能扰之，心静则欲不能牵之。 或曰：看此经者还得神磨而心不扰，还得心静而欲不牵，有验乎？ 答曰：昔唐懿宗皇帝有女号曰同昌公主，娶韦驸马。 公主欲其官嫌不自在，帝乃赐一宅，奇过王官，金楼玉阁，赐内库钱五百万贯。 公主心中不足，重奏曰：无宝货也。 皇帝罄内库之宝以实其宅，至于房拢户牖，无不差珍异宝饰之。 又以金银为栏药臼、食樻、水槽、金铛、金盆瓮，以银丝为笊篱箕筐，以水晶、瑠璃、玳瑁为床榻，以金龟银惊。 又琢五色为合盘，百宝为图案。 公主尚起欲心，又奏无米麦。 皇帝开内库，将到金麦银米五十斛赐与公主。 又奏曰：堂内无坐室帏幕。 於是帝又赐公主连珍帐幔，缀珍珠为边。 又赐与公主寒温药一把，冬悬即暖，夏悬即凉。 又赐公主九鸾宝钗一只，每戴之头上，有九色霞光。 公主每出，乘之七宝车驾，四面缀五色玉，香囊贮辟寒香、辟邪香、辟尘香，皆别国之贡也。 其笔上以杂宝龙脑，金屑刻镂，水晶码瑙等盘为龙凤瑞，四面缨络、珍珠装缀於笔上，周围之顶用碧玉莲花，上缀金珍一颗，珠上霞光高三尺，四面用金丝挂玉流苏，其中自然有天乐之音声。 每一出游，香风满路，馥郁芬芳，奇香半载不息，珠光灿烂，荧荧照耀。
chunks.translated_text:
Wang Gui bowed repeatedly and asked, “How did you come to wander here?” The master replied: “I recite the *Scripture of Supreme Clarity and Stillness of the Most High Lord Lao*. By following its teachings, I harmonize my virtue with Heaven and Earth.

*When one abides in constant clarity and stillness,
Heaven and Earth all return to them.*

Return home at once and seek your wife at the Wang household in Qingzhou.”

Wang Gui took leave of the master and departed. On the road, he hastened to Yunzhou, where his wife Han had already been laid to rest. He went directly to the Wang household in Qingzhou and recognized his wife’s child. The Wang family’s daughter, Shouniang, had been dead for three days when she revived and said: “I am the daughter of Han, Vice Minister of Rites. My father is now Prefect of Yunzhou.” Before she could finish explaining, Wang Gui arrived at the Wang residence. Seeing Shouniang, she immediately said: “My husband has come.” Her voice was nothing like Shouniang’s former tone. Wang Gui said: “Shouniang’s voice is now entirely Han’s.” He recounted the full story, and the Wang family then traveled to Yunzhou to meet Han’s parents. Her voice was unchanged from before. Both husband and wife suddenly awakened to the Great Dao, and they exhausted their family wealth to carve and print over one hundred thousand scrolls of scriptures, distributing them in all directions. They held a grand offering to the heavens in gratitude.

Afterward, Wang Gui and his wife returned to Temple Village to thank Master Tian. Upon completing their thanks, the master said: “You and your wife may cultivate together.” Wang Gui followed his words, resigning from office. He hung up his official robes, became a Daoist, and resided at the Fude Abbey in Chang’an. Han became a Daoist nun and lived at the Jade Capital Abbey. Each lived to one hundred and twenty years before passing.

The treatise says: *Abiding in stillness, yet responsive and penetrating—clarity and non-action.* Master Tian followed the scripture of the Most High and practiced the laws of Heaven. Above, he moved the vault of heaven; below, he communicated with the earth. He caused the Northern Emperor to descend and adjudicate grievances—truly, *when one abides in constant clarity and stillness, Heaven and Earth all return to them.*

Now, the spirit delights in clarity, yet the heart disturbs it; the heart delights in stillness, yet desire pulls it away. At birth, a person’s spirit is clear and their heart is still. As they grow, they are drawn by emotions and desires—this is the nature of life. Thus, the character for *desire* (欲) is composed of *valley* (谷) and *lack* (欠). *Valley* signifies the absence of leakage, while *lack* denotes insufficiency. When the spirit clings to love, it becomes *emotion*; when the heart clings to craving, it becomes *greed.*

Master Kangcang said: “Water is naturally clear, yet it cannot remain so when muddied by earth. Human nature is naturally still, yet it cannot remain so when disturbed by affairs.” *Disturbed* (汨) means chaos. The Most High spoke of these two principles: the spirit naturally delights in clarity and stillness, yet cannot attain them because the heart fails to embody the Dao of clarity and stillness. The heart harbors emotions of attachment, which disturb and disrupt it, preventing clarity and stillness. Thus, *the spirit delights in clarity, yet the heart disturbs it.* The heart is fundamentally inclined toward clarity and stillness, yet it cannot attain them because it is pulled by the greed of desire. Hence, *the heart delights in stillness, yet desire pulls it away.*

Master Wenzhong said: “The contented always delight in having no wants; the greedy always worry over insufficiency.” The contented delight in having no wants, so their spirit delights in clarity and their heart in stillness. The greedy worry over insufficiency, so their heart is disturbed and pulled by desire.

Master Baiyun said: “Desire is the source of greed and attachment, the root of excess and indulgence.” If one can embrace the Dao of clarity and stillness, the spirit will be clear. When the spirit is clear, the heart cannot disturb it; when the heart is still, desire cannot pull it away.

Some ask: “Can one who studies this scripture attain a spirit polished and undisturbed, a heart still and unburdened by desire? Is there proof?” The answer: In the past, Emperor Yizong of Tang had a daughter titled Princess Tongchang, who married the imperial son-in-law Wei. The princess found her official residence unsatisfactory, so the emperor bestowed upon her a mansion surpassing even the imperial palace—its halls and pavilions adorned with gold and jade. He granted her five million strings of cash from the inner treasury. Yet the princess was still not content. She petitioned again, saying she lacked treasures. The emperor emptied the inner treasury of its jewels to fill her mansion, adorning every chamber, door, and window with rare and precious gems. He had mortars and pestles, food chests, water troughs, cauldrons, and basins made of gold and silver; sieves and dustpans woven from silver thread; beds and couches fashioned from crystal, lapis lazuli, and tortoiseshell. Golden tortoises and silver cranes were placed about, and five-colored jade was carved into plates, with hundred-jeweled inlays forming patterns.

Still, the princess’s desires arose anew. She petitioned for grain, so the emperor opened the inner treasury and bestowed fifty *hu* of golden wheat and silver rice. She then complained that her halls lacked curtains and drapes. The emperor presented her with curtains of linked pearls, their edges strung with gems. He also gave her a *cold-warm medicine* fan—when hung in winter, it brought warmth; in summer, coolness. He bestowed upon her a nine-phoenix hairpin, which, when worn, emitted a nine-colored radiance. Whenever she ventured out, she rode in a seven-jeweled carriage, its sides inlaid with five-colored jade. Fragrant sachets held rare incenses—warding off cold, evil, and dust—all tributes from foreign lands. Her carriage’s canopy was adorned with carved dragons of mixed jewels and camphor, gold filigree, crystal, and agate. Dragons and phoenixes of auspicious design were set upon trays of onyx and carnelian, the canopy’s edges fringed with pearls. At its peak sat a lotus of green jade, crowned with a single golden pearl, its radiance rising three feet high. Golden threads suspended jade tassels, and from within, celestial music naturally resounded.

With every outing, fragrant winds filled the roads, their scent lingering for half a year. Her pearls gleamed brilliantly, casting a dazzling light.

Those who gazed upon it often saw only its brilliance, never its source. Though the princess’s wealth and nobility were boundless, her heart remained unsatisfied, her thoughts never reaching the realm of Penglai—thus she fell ill.

The princess resided within the palace, and from childhood had reverently recited the *Scripture of Constant Purity and Stillness* as spoken by the Most High Lord Lao. She summoned the imperial physician, Mi Zong, to treat her. By evening, she presented him with a two-inch candle of fragrant wax, bidding him take it home. Its scent was intensely pungent, spreading through the neighboring quarters. When visitors came to inquire, Mi Zong truthfully explained that it was the candle’s fragrance. The candle, two inches long, bore five-colored patterns; when lit, it grew warm, and by dawn its scent remained unexhausted, perceptible for three or four hundred paces. Its smoke ascended, forming the shapes of canopied pavilions and towers, with blossoms of rare and wondrous flowers.

The princess’s illness grew severe. She ordered her attendants to fetch the *Scripture of Purity and Stillness* by the Most High Lord Lao, and from a green jade casket she took a precious incense called "Heaven-Piercing Fragrance," burning it as she recited the sacred scripture. Before she could complete seven recitations, two crimson-robed messengers appeared, saying: "The Prefect summons you." The princess replied: "I am the daughter of an emperor—how dare you summon me?" She commanded her attendants to seize them, but they did not obey. The messengers said: "This concerns the affairs of the Netherworld—what does it matter that you are an imperial daughter?" With their hands, they pulled her to her feet. The princess cried out to her attendants, but none came to her aid; the two messengers seized and dragged her away.

They seemed to exit through Chang’an’s northern gate. After traveling several *li*, the princess’s feet grew sore, and she could walk no further. One messenger said: "I shall fetch a horse." In an instant, he led forth a white steed.

chunks.original_text: 阴暗之中行百余里，前到一大城中，亦有人烟。 公主曰：我乃饥也。 史曰：此中食皆焦竟烂心，不可闻见之。 须臾，风吹复初如故。 公主掩目不敢睹之。 又见数十男女，脱衣露体以火烧铁錍通红络其身，流血满地，皆成血泥。 公主问吏曰：此人何罪，受其苦痛？ 吏曰：此人於阳间乃奢佚之罪也。 公主惊曰：我还如何？ 吏曰：亦复如是。 须央之问，有鬼吏，头生两角，手提铁槌曰：公主脱衣。 公主曰：我乃帝王之女也。 鬼曰：此问不管帝王女，脱衣。 公主知不得已，而乃脱其冠服，默念《太上老君说常清静真经》一卷。 其鬼吏曰：疾脱衣。 公主念经，又脱一件。 其鬼吏遂以手揽其衣。 公主身如热油沃心而痛，又急念之，至三毒消灭之处，忽然见金光一道，其鬼吏尽皆乘空而礼拜，见一真人乘紫云而下，乃太极真人也。 太清官中闻念《混元老君常清静经》。 自念经一卷，已达三清之境，太上老君使吾下降幽狱，赦宥罪人。 公主至心礼拜真人。 公主曰：是弟子念经来，是当今懿宗皇帝女也。 真人曰：犯何罪而至此？ 其鬼吏曰：犯贪欲之罪。 须臾，众鬼史曰：乃酆都大帝。 皆礼太极真人也。 其太极真人身放光明，照耀幽狱。 真人谓其帝女曰：不可有欲，罪莫大於欲。 欲者，淫乱之本也。 罪莫大於贪。 贪者，僭妬之源也。 谓重也。 小则灭身，大则亡家。 世问不悟道者，不达清净之理，不知恬淡之机，唯知醴肴以充其口，富贵以荣其身，而顾其甘口之食，是伤命之斧，富贵奢华，惹怨之机。 既有其怨，岂不入地狱，而何不虚无清净、慈惠忠信、孝敬和顺、谨俭柔弱、清洁则与道同也。 无顾奢华守寂淡。 奢华者，地狱之因； 谨俭者，天堂之本。 真人谓公主曰：吾救汝，阳问能改奢华之欲否？ 公主再拜曰：能改。 真人曰：吾有五戒十善、六斋三会、五腊五忌，汝能行之？ 公主曰：能行。 真人曰：能持则为天官，不能持则为下鬼。 真人曰：五戒者，一不杀生，二不嗜欲，三不口是心非，四不盗物，五不淫乱。 十善者，一孝养父母，二忠奉君师，三忘心万物，四忍怒防非，五止争解恶，六损己救穷，七生养济人，八道边义井植树，九为人兴利除害，十赞三宝经，为人解说，常生善念。 凡人常行此五戒十善，别有天人善神卫护，永免灾殃，长臻福佑，唯在坚诚。 而公主曰：何名六斋？ 每月初一日、初八日、十四日、十五日、二十九日。 公主曰：何名十斋？ 每月初一日、初八日、十四日、十五日、十八日、二十三日、二十四日、二十八日、二十九日、三十日，此十日乃十方救苦天尊救度地狱三涂五苦应诸等众罪魂。 公主曰：何名三会？ 真人曰：正月七日迁举上会，七月七日庆生中会，十月五日建生下会。 公主曰：何名五腊？ 真人曰：正月一日天腊，五月五日地腊，七月七日道德腊，十月五日民岁腊，十二月王侯腊。 公主曰：何名五忌？ 真人曰：一忌甲子太一真君录人罪犯，二忌庚申三尸言人罪犯，三忌本命星官计人功行，四忌八节八神计人善恶，五忌三元天地水三官录人罪福。 太极真人曰：遇逢此日，可设醮修斋，持经供养，以析求景佑。 公主再拜礼真人曰：一一遵依道旨。 真人乃放光明，照其幽狱皆得生天矣。

Through murky darkness they journeyed over a hundred *li* before arriving at a great city, where signs of human habitation appeared. The princess said, "I am hungry." The attendant replied, "The food here is all charred to the core—its stench is unbearable to see or smell." In an instant, the wind blew and all returned to its former state. The princess covered her eyes, unable to bear the sight.

Then she saw dozens of men and women, stripped naked, their bodies seared by red-hot iron rods, blood flowing to the ground until it became a mire of gore. The princess asked the attendant, "What crimes have these people committed to suffer such torment?" The attendant replied, "In the world above, these are the sins of extravagance and indulgence."

The princess gasped, "And what of my fate?" The attendant said, "It will be the same." In that moment, a ghostly official appeared, two horns sprouting from his head, wielding an iron hammer. He commanded, "Princess, remove your clothes." The princess said, "I am the daughter of an emperor!" The ghost replied, "This court does not recognize imperial daughters—remove your clothes." Knowing resistance was futile, she began to remove her headdress and robes, silently reciting *The Supreme Lord Lao’s Scripture on Constant Purity and Tranquility*.

The ghostly official urged, "Hurry, remove your clothes!" As she recited, she removed another garment. The ghost then reached out to seize her clothing. The princess felt as though boiling oil had been poured into her heart, the pain unbearable. She recited more urgently, reaching the passage on the dissolution of the Three Poisons. Suddenly, a golden light appeared, and the ghostly officials all rose into the air in reverence. A perfected being descended upon purple clouds—it was the Supreme Ultimate Perfected One.

From the Palace of Great Purity came the sound of recitation: *The Scripture of Primordial Lord Lao on Constant Purity and Tranquility*. "By reciting this scripture once, you have reached the realm of the Three Clarities. The Supreme Lord Lao has sent me to descend into the nether prison and absolve the sins of the condemned." The princess bowed deeply to the perfected one.

The princess said, "It was by reciting this scripture that I came here—I am the daughter of the present Emperor Yizong." The perfected one asked, "What crime have you committed to be here?" The ghostly officials replied, "The sin of greed and desire." Just then, the assembled ghostly officials exclaimed, "It is the Great Emperor of Fengdu!" All paid homage to the Supreme Ultimate Perfected One.

The Supreme Ultimate Perfected One radiated light, illuminating the nether prison. He addressed the imperial daughter: "There is no greater sin than desire. Desire is the root of licentiousness and disorder. There is no greater sin than greed. Greed is the source of usurpation and envy. To weigh it lightly is to destroy oneself; to weigh it heavily is to ruin one’s family. Those in the world who do not awaken to the Dao do not comprehend the principle of purity and tranquility. They do not know the subtlety of contentment, only seeking fine foods to sate their mouths and wealth and honor to adorn their bodies. Yet the sweetness of such food is the axe that severs life, and the extravagance of riches and luxury is the mechanism that invites resentment. Once resentment arises, how can one avoid the hells? Why not embrace emptiness and purity, kindness and benevolence, loyalty and trust, filial piety and harmony, modesty and frugality, gentleness and humility, and cleanliness—thus aligning with the Dao? Do not cling to extravagance; uphold simplicity. Extravagance is the cause of hell; frugality is the foundation of heaven."

The Supreme Ultimate Perfected One said to the princess, "I shall save you. In the world above, will you reform your extravagant desires?" The princess bowed again and said, "I will reform." The perfected one said, "I have the Five Precepts and Ten Good Deeds, the Six Fasts and Three Assemblies, the Five Laba Festivals and Five Taboo Days—can you observe them?" The princess replied, "I can."

The perfected one said, "If you uphold them, you will become a celestial official; if you fail, you will become a lowly ghost." He continued, "The Five Precepts are: first, do not kill; second, do not indulge in desire; third, do not speak falsely with the heart; fourth, do not steal; fifth, do not engage in licentiousness. The Ten Good Deeds are: first, honor and support your parents; second, be loyal to your sovereign and teachers; third, let go of all things in your heart; fourth, restrain anger and prevent wrongdoing; fifth, cease conflict and resolve enmity; sixth, humble yourself to aid the poor; seventh, give life and succor to others; eighth, dig wells and plant trees by the roadside; ninth, benefit others and eliminate harm; tenth, praise the Three Treasures, explain the scriptures to others, and always harbor good thoughts. Those who constantly practice these Five Precepts and Ten Good Deeds will have celestial beings and benevolent spirits protect them, forever free from disaster and ever blessed with good fortune—provided their resolve is steadfast."

The princess asked, "What are the Six Fasts?" The perfected one replied, "The first, eighth, fourteenth, fifteenth, and twenty-ninth days of each month." The princess asked, "What are the Ten Fasts?" The perfected one said, "The first, eighth, fourteenth, fifteenth, eighteenth, twenty-third, twenty-fourth, twenty-eighth, twenty-ninth, and thirtieth days of each month. On these ten days, the Heavenly Worthies of the Ten Directions Who Save from Suffering deliver the souls of the condemned from the Three Paths and Five Sufferings."

The princess asked, "What are the Three Assemblies?" The perfected one replied, "The seventh day of the first month is the Upper Assembly of Ascension; the seventh day of the seventh month is the Middle Assembly of Celebration; the fifth day of the tenth month is the Lower Assembly of Establishment."

The princess asked, "What are the Five Laba Festivals?" The perfected one said, "The first day of the first month is the Heavenly Laba; the fifth day of the fifth month is the Earthly Laba; the seventh day of the seventh month is the Laba of the Dao and Virtue; the fifth day of the tenth month is the Laba of the People’s Year; the twelfth month is the Laba of Kings and Lords."

The princess asked, "What are the Five Taboo Days?" The perfected one replied, "First, the day of Jiazi, when the True Lord Taiyi records people’s transgressions; second, the day of Gengshen, when the Three Corpses report people’s sins; third, one’s own birthday, when the Star Officials tally one’s merits and deeds; fourth, the Eight Festivals, when the Eight Spirits assess people’s good and evil; fifth, the Three Yuan days, when the Three Officials of Heaven, Earth, and Water record people’s sins and blessings."

The Supreme Ultimate Perfected One said, "On these days, you may perform rituals, observe fasts, recite scriptures, and make offerings to pray for protection." The princess bowed again to the perfected one and said, "I will follow the Dao’s decrees in every detail." The Supreme Ultimate Perfected One then radiated light, illuminating the nether prison, and all within were reborn in heaven.

chunks.original_text: 劲使碧衣童子，引公主速归。 真人乃升天而去化。 北阴酆都大帝、一切鬼神皆大欢喜。 其碧衣童子引公主至一金门已，推而入，其公主忽然惊觉。 公主身在碧牙床上，盖其锦被。 公主开目视之，见驸马、官人在侧，乃围而泣之。 公主拥被而坐。 宫人曰：公主睡多时，不敢惊动。 公主曰：富贵乃若石中燧火，荣华如水上浮湛，时光有若南柯一梦。 其病顿愈。 公主乃入官内奏帝，所有珍宝尽数还纳於内库，乞身归道。 帝曰：何也？ 公主具说阴府之事，一一奏帝。 帝乃欢喜，依公主所奏，以崇仙坊金仙观改为玉真观。 公主自入观之后，而不出观门，虽有贵戚、驸马亲等，公主令人监门，并不能得见公主，每日唯念《太上老君说常清静真经》，不曾惰慢。 至三年后，复见真人於红光之中，乃谓公主曰：上升至近，证为天仙，火急修为功果。 道罢，不见。 公主乃建黄录大醮。 至上元十五夜，鸾鹤自天而降，月华如昼，香风馥郁。 其鹤至於庭前，公主乘鸾背，冉冉登空而去。 遗留下《唐多令词》一阕云：性命两如何，奢华勿太过。 守贞康谨俭安和，以己方人无横祸。 叹绿分，少贵多，也啰。 击破是非窝，敲开名利锁。 澄心取性且蹉跎，暗想高低哀与乐。 猛省悟，若南柯，也啰。 人皆具说。 人人皆写其词，京师乃为供养。 此者同昌公主悟此《清静真经》乃为验乎。 故曰，夫人神好清而心扰之，人心好净而欲牵之。 论曰：能守清净者，食欲不能移，险阻不能危； 不以禄位惑其志，不以贫贱改其心，不以毁誉度其色，不以荣华乱其神。 同昌入梦酆都，感太极真人说戒，能受之，猛拾富贵而甘其寂淡，三戒行周备，可为仙人也。 常能遣其欲而心自静，澄其心而神自清。 欲者，流浪之相； 澄者，定水之相。 此二句是太上再言去爱拾欲之心。 若能去爱，不生情欲，而不起贪心，则神自静而心自清也。 若能流浪之爱想而心息，又若更能澄心如水定之相，则皎洁不动； 皎洁不动则神自然清静。 故云常能遣其欲，而心自静，澄其心而神自清。 文中子曰：拾其所争不争，乃遣其欲而心自静。 万物所弃则无贪，无贪则心自澄矣。 能澄心者，其神自清。 如此者，亦修真之士不亦悟清静之道也。 白云翁云：君子以清静洗其心，小人以责爱移其心。 是以圣人常能遣其欲而心自静，澄其心而神自清。 刘子曰：神者，心之主，是故神静而心和，心和而形全； 神乱而心荡，心荡则伤其形。 先理其神。 故以圣人以恬和养其神，和者，去嗜欲也。 如此则以和养其神则安於内，清思栖心则不诱於外，神和心清，形无累矣。 无累者，则因遣欲者也。 故云遣其欲。 问曰：自古人能遣其欲？ 答曰：有之。 昔有南史时宋帝朝，有宰相元田夫有贪欲之心。 国朝有事，不唯大小，须要财帛而后行其事。 偶因街下二人，因醉而争淫滥之事，而杀死一人。 田夫语於杀人者：汝能出绢千疋，可令汝活。 其人出绢八百疋。 田夫曰：未能可免。 被杀之家闻之某，愿出绢一千疋，可使此人偿命。 杀人者怕死，出绢一千二百疋，被杀之家无绢可酬，乃断判醉而有慢，可次六十而放之。 百姓无处告论，民受其屈者多矣。 征敛无度，家中修楼阁庭台，用其金碧千有余问，制过王宅；

The stalwart azure-clad youth then led the princess to hasten her return. The Perfected One ascended into heaven and departed, transformed. The Great Emperor of the Northern Yin Fengdu and all the spirits and ghosts rejoiced greatly. The azure-clad youth guided the princess to a golden gate, pushed her through, and suddenly the princess awoke with a start. She found herself lying on a jade-inlaid bed, covered with brocade quilts. Opening her eyes, she saw her husband, the imperial son-in-law, and the court officials beside her, weeping as they surrounded her. The princess sat up, clutching the quilt. A palace attendant said, "Princess, you have slept for a long time; we dared not disturb you." The princess replied, "Wealth and honor are like sparks struck from stone, glory and splendor like fleeting reflections on water—time passes as in a dream of Southern Branch. Her illness was instantly cured.

The princess then entered the palace to address the emperor, returning all her treasures to the imperial treasury and begging to renounce her worldly ties to follow the Dao. The emperor asked, "Why?" The princess recounted in full the events of the netherworld. The emperor, overjoyed, granted her request and transformed the Golden Immortal Abbey in the Revered Immortal Precinct into the Jade Perfection Abbey. After entering the abbey, the princess never again crossed its threshold. Though nobles, relatives, and even her husband sought audience, the princess ordered the gates guarded, and none could see her. Each day, she recited only the *Supreme Venerable Lord’s Explanation of the Perfect Scripture of Constant Purity and Tranquility*, never growing lax.

Three years later, she again beheld the Perfected One within a radiance of red light, who said to her, "Your ascension draws near; you shall attain the rank of celestial immortal. Hasten to cultivate merit and fruition." With these words, the Perfected One vanished. The princess then performed the great Yellow Register Retreat.

On the fifteenth night of the Upper Prime Festival, phoenixes and cranes descended from heaven. The moonlight was as bright as day, and fragrant breezes filled the air. The cranes alighted in the courtyard, and the princess mounted a phoenix’s back, ascending slowly into the sky. She left behind a *Tang Duoling* lyric:

*Life and fate—how to weigh them?*
*Lavish splendor—do not overindulge.*
*Guard chastity, health, frugality, peace, and harmony;*
*Measure yourself against others, and no calamity shall befall.*
*Alas! The young grow old, the noble grow poor—*
*Such is the way of the world.*

*Shatter the nest of strife,*
*Strike open the lock of fame and gain.*
*Calm the heart, refine the nature, let time slip by;*
*In silence, ponder the highs and lows, sorrow and joy.*
*Suddenly awakened—*
*It was all a dream of Southern Branch,*
*Such is the way of the world.*

All who heard it spoke of it, and everyone copied the lyric. In the capital, it was revered and offerings were made. This was the verification of Princess Tongchang’s enlightenment through the *Scripture of Constant Purity and Tranquility*.

Thus it is said: The spirit delights in purity, yet the heart disturbs it; the heart delights in clarity, yet desires entangle it.

It is further stated: Those who can maintain purity and tranquility cannot be swayed by gluttony or craving, nor imperiled by peril or hardship. They are not deluded by rank or emolument, nor do poverty and lowliness alter their resolve. They are unmoved by slander or praise, nor is their spirit disordered by glory or splendor. Princess Tongchang entered the dream of Fengdu, was moved by the admonitions of the Supreme Ultimate Perfected One, and accepted them. She resolutely abandoned wealth and honor, embracing solitude and simplicity. Having fulfilled the Three Precepts in full, she became a perfected immortal.

One must constantly dispel desires, and the heart will naturally grow still; calm the heart, and the spirit will naturally become clear. Desire is the appearance of drifting and wandering; clarity is the appearance of still water. These two lines are the Supreme Venerable Lord’s repeated exhortation to relinquish attachment and abandon desire. If one can let go of attachment, no emotional desires arise, and no greed takes root, then the spirit will naturally grow still and the heart will naturally become clear. If one can extinguish the wandering attachments of the heart and still it, and further calm the heart to the stillness of water, then purity will remain unshaken. Unshaken purity allows the spirit to become naturally clear and tranquil. Thus it is said: Constantly dispel desires, and the heart will naturally grow still; calm the heart, and the spirit will naturally become clear.

Master Wenzi said: Abandon what others contend for, and do not contend—thus dispelling desires, the heart will naturally grow still. What all things discard, one should not covet; without covetousness, the heart will naturally become clear. One who can calm the heart will find their spirit naturally clear. Such is the awakening of the Dao of purity and tranquility for those who cultivate the truth.

The Old Man of White Clouds said: The noble person washes their heart with purity and tranquility; the petty person is swayed by avarice and attachment. Therefore, the sage constantly dispels desires, and the heart naturally grows still; calms the heart, and the spirit naturally becomes clear.

Master Liu said: The spirit is the master of the heart. Thus, when the spirit is tranquil, the heart is harmonious, and when the heart is harmonious, the body is whole. When the spirit is disordered, the heart is agitated, and when the heart is agitated, the body is harmed. First, govern the spirit. Therefore, the sage nurtures the spirit with serenity and harmony. Harmony means relinquishing cravings and desires. Thus, nurturing the spirit with harmony brings inner peace, while dwelling in pure thought and settling the heart prevents external allurements. When spirit is harmonious and heart is clear, the body is unburdened. Unburdened, one has dispelled desires. Thus it is said: Dispel desires.

Someone asked: Has anyone since ancient times been able to dispel desires?
The answer: Yes. In the Southern History, during the reign of Emperor Song, there was a prime minister, Yuan Tianfu, who was greedy and covetous. In all state affairs, great or small, nothing proceeded without bribes of silk and wealth. Once, two men in the street, drunk, quarreled over a licentious matter and killed one of them. Yuan Tianfu said to the killer: "If you can produce a thousand bolts of silk, I can spare your life." The man offered eight hundred bolts. Yuan Tianfu said: "That is not enough to secure your pardon." The family of the deceased, hearing this, offered a thousand bolts to have the killer executed. Fearing death, the killer produced twelve hundred bolts. The deceased’s family, unable to match the sum, ruled that the killing was committed in drunkenness and with negligence, and sentenced the man to sixty strokes before releasing him. The people had no recourse for grievances, and many suffered injustice. Yuan Tianfu’s exactions knew no bounds; he built pavilions and terraces in his home, using over a thousand measures of gold and jade, surpassing even the imperial palace.

chunks.original_text: 美女盈庭，皆国色者； 每一食，可费用钱百贯。 朝欢暮乐，又好黄白之术，多取其利。 忽有道人立於门前曰：能黄白之术。 田夫闻之，急令人召至宅。 田夫见之，降阶而揖之，问曰：有何术教予？ 先生曰：愿求一醉。 田夫曰：不见其术，先要我酒饮得，非欲乎。 先生曰：想君回生作死，回死作生，率敛无度，屋宇千问，金玉满库，美女千人，淫欲至甚。 又求黄白之术。 汝孰欲过乎，而谓我欲也。 田夫被先生责之，而怒曰：尔乃何处野人？ 焉放触我。 令左右执之。
chunks.translated_text: The courtyard teemed with beauties, all of national renown. Each meal cost a hundred strings of cash. From dawn to dusk, he indulged in pleasure, and was fond of the arts of alchemy, profiting greatly from them. Suddenly, a Daoist appeared at the gate and declared, "I possess the arts of alchemy." Hearing this, Yuan Tianfu hastily summoned him to his residence. Upon meeting, Yuan descended the steps to bow and asked, "What arts can you teach me?" The master replied, "I wish only to drink my fill." Yuan said, "You have not shown your arts, yet you demand wine first—are you not greedy?" The master replied, "You turn life into death and death into life, extorting without measure. Your halls number a thousand, your vaults overflow with gold and jade, your concubines a thousand, your lust boundless. Yet you seek the arts of alchemy. What desire could surpass yours? Do you accuse *me* of greed?" Shamed by the master’s rebuke, Yuan grew furious and cried, "Where is this rustic from? How dare he insult me!" He ordered his attendants to seize him.

chunks.original_text: 忽然不见。 乃遗《点绛唇》 词一阕云：富贵荣华，高官一品功勋大。 由自贪爱，待铁打亭堂盖。 家计方成，堤备阎王怪。 如何奈？ 怎生得解，难免诸人债。 田夫见而闷闷不乐，归小阁中。 忽於睡梦，见一块黄金，田夫喜而自取，身堕地下，冥冥而去。 忽见甚明，田夫觑时，睹数百人戴其桎梏，或拚或昂，以大石压身者。 又见一牌上写贪爱之狱。 忽见一白衣人披发而言曰：相公来何晚矣？ 等侯相公多时。 相公曰：尔乃何人也？ 其人曰：我乃被杀之人也。 相公受绢一千二百疋，不令偿命。 只要相公还我命。 以悮杀数百余人，叫相公将我金来，并珍宝等。 田夫惊而走之，众人拽住，为索其债。 又数人抬一巨石，长三丈，厚五尺，但压相公。 然后左右拽倒相公，欲抬其石压之。 或有一人喝住：且休压相公，其人寿数未尽，更有六年之寿。 相公觑时，乃是献黄白之术者。 遂引田夫於狱中坐一大石。 先生曰：吾太白星君也。 相公官居一品，不积德行，唯有心责意欲，是祸之本也。 相公曰：今日深谢先生相救，粉骨难忘。 先生曰：相公自来曾念甚经？ 答曰：曾念《太上老君清静真经》。 先生曰：怪然有道气也。 是经云力能过吾也。 相公何不闻经内常能遣其欲而心自静，澄其心而神自清？ 相公曰：居，吾语汝。 夫耳目诱於声色，鼻口之於香味，肌体之於安适，皆出於欲也。 此欲若不遣之，则精神驰骇而不守，志气糜散则耗五脏陷而不能安。 嗜欲连绵於心腑，蔓衍於荒淫之浪，留连於是非之境。 如此者，而不以财德倡生，盖以寡矣。 是以圣人清目而不视，静耳而不听，闭口而不言，弃心而忘害，贵身而贱物。 故尊势而忘动，乐道而忘贪，故厚利而不能容身而处，适情而游。 一炁浩浩，盖首於故养形而性自全，心不劳而道自至。 先生曰：相公旦夕宜千万省之。 田夫辞先生。
chunks.translated_text:
Suddenly, he vanished without a trace. In his place, he left behind a *lyric to the tune "Dian Jiang Chun"*:

Wealth and honor, glory and splendor,
High office of the first rank, mighty deeds of merit—
All stem from greed and craving,
Awaiting the iron-forged halls of judgment.
Your household affairs now settled,
Yet the King of Hell prepares his reproach.
What recourse remains?
How to find deliverance?
The debts of all men are inescapable.

Yuan Tianfu read the words and grew sullen and displeased. He retired to his private chamber. In his sleep, he dreamed he saw a lump of gold; overjoyed, he reached to take it, only to plummet to the ground and descend into darkness. Suddenly, all grew bright. Yuan looked around and saw hundreds of men shackled in fetters, some groaning, some wailing, their bodies crushed beneath great stones. He saw a placard inscribed: *"The Prison of Greed and Craving."*

Suddenly, a man in white robes, his hair unbound, spoke: "My lord, why have you come so late? We have awaited you for a long time." Yuan asked, "Who are you?" The man replied, "I am one of those you had killed. You accepted twelve hundred bolts of silk and spared my life—yet all I ask is that you restore it. You have wrongfully taken the lives of hundreds. Now, my lord, return my gold and treasures." Terrified, Yuan turned to flee, but the crowd seized him, demanding repayment of his debts. Several men hoisted a massive stone, three *zhang* long and five *chi* thick, ready to crush him. Then, as they dragged him down to place the stone upon him, a voice cried out: "Hold! Do not crush him yet—his allotted lifespan is not yet exhausted. He has six more years."

Yuan looked and saw it was the master who had offered the arts of alchemy. The master led him to a great stone within the prison and seated him there. He said, "I am the Star Lord of Venus. Though you hold the highest rank, you have not accumulated virtue or right conduct. Your heart is consumed by greed and desire—this is the root of misfortune." Yuan replied, "Today, I deeply thank you for your rescue. Even if I ground my bones to dust, I could not repay you." The master asked, "Have you ever recited any scriptures?" Yuan answered, "I have recited the *Classic of the Dao and Its Virtue by the Supreme Lord Lao, on Purity and Stillness*." The master said, "No wonder you bear the aura of the Dao. This scripture’s power surpasses even mine. Have you not heard its words: *If one constantly dispels desire, the heart becomes still of itself; if one settles the heart, the spirit becomes clear of itself*?"

Yuan said, "Pray, instruct me." The master continued: "The ears and eyes are enticed by sounds and sights, the nose and mouth by fragrances and flavors, the body by comfort and ease—all arise from desire. If these desires are not dispelled, the spirit scatters and cannot be preserved; the will and qi dissipate, harming the five viscera and leaving them unsettled. When cravings coil within the heart and spread like wild vines through the waves of excess, lingering in the realm of right and wrong—without cultivating virtue through wealth and conduct, how can one hope to live long? Thus, the sage purifies his eyes and does not see, stills his ears and does not hear, seals his mouth and does not speak, abandons the heart and forgets harm, values the body and scorns material things. He esteems power yet forgets action, delights in the Dao and forgets greed. Thus, even great profit cannot confine him, and he roams freely in accord with his nature. With qi vast and boundless, he returns to nurturing his form, and his nature is preserved whole; his heart is not wearied, and the Dao comes to him of itself."

The master said, "My lord, you must reflect on this day and night, ten thousand times over." Yuan then took his leave of the master.

Do you accuse *me* of greed?" Shamed by the master’s rebuke, Yuan grew furious and cried, "Where is this rustic from? How dare he insult me!" He ordered his attendants to seize him.

chunks.original_text: 而有唤元相公，相公觑时，乃被杀人赶来，相公乃蹶倒及地。 忽然惊觉，冷汗流体，心怖而不已。 是时田夫猛省曰：财者祸之源，贪者罪之本也。 遂已解印休官，出宝库之财赈济贫穷，深闺之妓使嫁良人，施其宅舍尽作官观，身脱罗衣而穿布素，口养粝食，顿吃淡饭，每日唯念《太上老君清静真经》。 遵而行之十年之期，忽见本来梦见者先生。 田夫见而礼之。 先生曰：进道数年，甚有劳乎？ 今已释冤债，但无可以升於仙路。 真遣欲忘贪之人，乃澄心养神之侣。 今已朱陵挂号，碧落标名。 还与神丹一粒，可吞之。 先生曰：已不食矣。 故《仙经内传》 云：饮食不止身不轻，声色不止神不清，思虑不止心不宁，心不宁而神不灵，神不灵，功不成。 其要道也，不在瞻星礼斗，苦己劳形，唯在方寸，湛然无所。 神仙之道，永保长生。 故道者，即修心者也。 老君曰：道以心得，心以道明。 心明则道降，道降者神明则在身也。 如油火在扈，明从火起，火因油在； 灶因油润，油藉扈停。 四者若废，明何在焉？ 亦如明绿神照，神托心安，如形有心，道全一物，不足何依焉？ 所以为之神明。 神明者，目见、耳闻，意知心觉，分明物理，玄微悉析。 此为神明，切宜记之。 朱陵官相候。 忽然不见。 田夫乃依龙虎相交，阴阳间隔，五行离合，水火既济而修之，乃筑环墙而修之，炼更三年，通前一纪之数。 至重阳日，田夫乘空而去之。 后人推墙开门，看之而不见田夫，唯见《清经》一部，案上花笺一幅词，《寄唐多令》云：性命两如何？ 根元牢闭锁。 守阳魂、阴魄尽消磨，运火周天烹大药。 向海底、看红波。 也啰。 贵贱片时过，荣华一掷梭。 待三千、功满行成，合骖鸾凤游碧落。 朝玉帝、应仙科。 也啰。
chunks.translated_text:
Then someone called out, "Minister Yuan!" As the minister looked, he saw he was being pursued by murderers—he stumbled and fell to the ground.

Suddenly he awoke in a cold sweat, his heart trembling without cease. At that moment, the peasant Farmer Yuan came to a sharp realization: "Wealth is the source of disaster, and greed the root of sin." Thereupon he removed his official seal and resigned his post, distributing the treasures of the imperial vault to relieve the poor. He arranged for the courtesans in his inner chambers to marry respectable men, and converted his mansions entirely into Daoist abbeys. Casting off his silken robes, he donned plain cloth; his diet became coarse grains and bland fare. Each day, he recited only the *Classic of Supreme Clarity by Lord Lao*. Following its precepts for a decade, he suddenly encountered the master from his original dream.

Farmer Yuan bowed in reverence. The master said, "You have advanced on the Way for several years—has it been arduous? Now that you have released your karmic debts, nothing bars your ascent to the immortal path. Truly, one who forgets desire and relinquishes greed becomes a companion in the cultivation of a serene heart and nurtured spirit. You have now been registered in the Vermilion Numinosity and your name inscribed in the Azure Vault. Here is a divine elixir—swallow it."

Farmer Yuan replied, "I no longer eat."

The master said, "Thus the *Inner Transmission of the Immortal Classic* states: 'If eating does not cease, the body will not become light; if sensual pleasures do not cease, the spirit will not become clear; if thoughts do not cease, the heart will not be at peace. If the heart is not at peace, the spirit will not be efficacious; if the spirit is not efficacious, the work will not be accomplished.' The essential Way does not lie in gazing at stars or worshipping the Dipper, nor in tormenting the self or exhausting the body—it lies solely in the square inch of the heart, utterly still and empty of all things. The Way of immortality is the eternal preservation of life. Thus, the Dao is nothing other than the cultivation of the heart."

Lord Lao said: "The Dao is attained through the heart; the heart is illuminated by the Dao. When the heart is bright, the Dao descends; when the Dao descends, the numinous clarity resides within the body. Like oil and flame in a lamp: light arises from fire, fire depends on oil; the vessel is moistened by oil, oil rests in the vessel. If any of these four are lacking, where is the light? Likewise, luminous spirit shines forth, spirit rests in a tranquil heart, just as form possesses heart. The Dao is complete in one thing—what else could it rely upon? This is what is called numinous clarity. Numinous clarity is seeing with the eyes, hearing with the ears, knowing with the mind, and perceiving with the heart—discerning the principles of things, analyzing the subtle and profound. This is numinous clarity—take heed and remember it."

An official from the Vermilion Numinosity Hall awaited him. Suddenly, the master vanished.

Thereafter, Farmer Yuan followed the interplay of dragon and tiger, the alternation of yin and yang, the separation and union of the Five Phases, and the harmonization of water and fire. He built an encircling wall and cultivated within it, refining for three more years, completing a full twelve-year cycle. On the Double Ninth Festival, Farmer Yuan ascended into the void.

Later, people broke open the gate of the wall and searched, but Farmer Yuan was nowhere to be seen. They found only a copy of the *Classic of Clarity* and, on the desk, a sheet of floral stationery bearing the lyric to the tune *Remembering Tang Duo*:

*How fare both life and nature?*
*The root and origin are firmly sealed.*
*Guard the yang soul—*
*yin and po dissolve away.*
*Circulate the fire through the celestial cycle,*
*refining the great elixir.*
*Look to the sea’s depths—*
*behold the crimson waves.*
*Yo-lo!*

*Riches and rank pass in an instant,*
*glory and splendor like a shuttle cast aside.*
*Wait until the three thousand deeds are complete,*
*the work perfected—*
*then ride phoenix and simurgh*
*to roam the Azure Vault.*
*To the Jade Emperor’s court,*
*answer the immortal’s summons.*
*Yo-lo!*

chunks.original_text: 论曰：杳杳冥冥，其中有精； 恍恍惚惚，其中有物。 自先生有元田夫，遣其欲而心自静，澄其心而神自清，心静神清而自至，此之谓道。 至若无修之实有，今已身超碧落而拜玉帝，可谓得道矣。 自然六欲不生，三毒消灭。 六欲者，六贼也。 何名六贼？ 六贼者、眼、耳、鼻、舌、身、意。 三毒者，三尸。 何名三尸？ 三尸者，上尸彭琚，管人之上丹田，使人好华饰之毒； 中尸彭质，主人之中丹田，使人好贪欲、嗜滋味之毒； 下尸彭矫，主人之下丹田，好淫欲疾妬之毒。 上句言人禀道，常能遣流浪之相，而心自静，澄其心，如水定之相，神自清也。 太上言，若人能心静神清，自然六欲不生，三尸不为，三毒乃消灭。 故云六欲不生，三毒消灭。 文中子曰：君子之学则进於道，进於道者，自然六欲不生，三毒消灭。 小人之学则进於利，进於利者，则六欲乃生，三毒不灭。 《易》曰：君子以恐惧修省。 故六欲不生，三毒不起，则自消也。 何人能六欲不生，更得三毒消灭？ 答曰：有之。 昔唐贞观年问，有一人名沈会，因有欲心，取受民财，事发配於竹兰。 日夕常念《太上老君清静经》，罢面望泰山而礼拜，言曰：惟愿得还乡里。 有束岳泰山府君之子，乃炳灵公也，因游西岳赴会，回见沈会念《清静经》，灵公乃於虚空之中言曰：其人不可得也。 回东岳语於府君，府君曰：善哉，令使取沈会於偏阁之中，坐时，天色正午。 见朱衣吏曰：府君召汝足下。 沈会曰：那府君？ 吏曰：乃东岳府君。 沈会大惊，急取章服，与史同行，至於城外。 其吏曰：即今脚下，至泰山三千余里。 沈会曰：何能得到？ 其史曰：此问借一疋马。 沈会只於树下等候，其吏入於庙中，须臾牵一疋青马至，但小如驴。 吏曰：乘马可紧合目。 沈会上马，合目，急如猛风。 史曰：开目。 乃见一城，遂入其城。 近城只多荆棘。 又至一府衙，左右皆铁衣卫护。 其吏乃牵住下马，引沈会入于府衙。 兵史乃问曰：何人也？ 奉府君勑，故取之入於第三重门。 史曰：官人但於此候，容某先入报之。 吏既入去，不多时，有一通引官出曰：府君召沈会官人来。 沈会急随而入之，乃至於一宝殿，四面皆珠帘绛幕，膀其殿日朝曦之殿。 其吏止沈会於殿下，左右皆金甲鬼兵侍卫。 有二碧衣童子乃轴其帘，见一人正坐，戴远游冠，衣青色盘龙衮服，手执寒玉珪。 傍立一人，是金蛾帽子，茜红，系蓝靛玉带，年可三十许。 令碧衣童子请沈会上殿。 沈会上其殿，战战兢兢，步不能移。 碧衣童子策上殿，沈会拜之。 府君约拜，令左右取榻赐坐。 府君曰：凡人为恶，不为人诛，必为鬼戮之。 汝昨有至欲之罪，而得此报，故有责配之报。 汝能念《太上老君清静经》，一年之间，诵之万卷之余，其德甚重，至能拜礼於吾，奉天帝之劝，不令汝入於轮回之路。 汝念此经而能诵之，若通其义，依而行之，乃与人讲论。 若化一人归道，其功以加焉，不为上仙而为神仙，不为神仙而为地仙，不为地仙而为鬼仙，安能入生死之路？ 语毕，有一鬼官着绯衣，乃铺文字於案上，而指之曰：有慕仁轨执质笏殿下，乃沈会之姑夫也。 沈会回面而不敢顾。 王曰：汝既为官，任束海郡牧，而不能清白治化於民，却生贪欲之心，杀平人阿赵。
chunks.translated_text:
A Discourse:

Vast and obscure, therein lies essence;
dim and indistinct, therein lies substance.
Ever since Master Yuan the Farmer existed, he cast off desire and his mind became still; he settled his mind and his spirit became clear. When the mind is still and the spirit clear, the Dao arrives of itself—this is called the Way.

As for the reality of cultivation without cultivation: now his body has ascended to the Azure Vault and he bows before the Jade Emperor—this may truly be called attaining the Dao. Naturally, the six desires do not arise, and the three poisons are extinguished.

The six desires are the six thieves. What are the six thieves? They are the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and intent. The three poisons are the three corpses. What are the three corpses? The upper corpse is Peng Ju, who governs the upper cinnabar field and instills in people the poison of fondness for adornment; the middle corpse is Peng Zhi, who governs the middle cinnabar field and instills the poison of greed, gluttony, and craving for rich flavors; the lower corpse is Peng Jiao, who governs the lower cinnabar field and instills the poison of lust, jealousy, and malice.

The preceding lines speak of how one who embraces the Dao constantly dispels the state of drifting and restlessness, so that the mind becomes still. When the mind is settled, like still water, the spirit naturally becomes clear. The Most High has said: if one can still the mind and clarify the spirit, naturally the six desires will not arise, the three corpses will not act, and the three poisons will be extinguished. Thus it is said: the six desires do not arise, and the three poisons are extinguished.

Master Wenzi said: the learning of the noble person advances toward the Dao. One who advances toward the Dao naturally does not generate the six desires, and the three poisons are extinguished. The learning of the petty person advances toward profit. One who advances toward profit generates the six desires, and the three poisons are not extinguished.

The *Book of Changes* says: the noble person cultivates and examines himself with reverence and fear. Thus, when the six desires do not arise and the three poisons do not stir, they extinguish themselves. Who can ensure the six desires do not arise and further extinguish the three poisons?

The answer is: such a person exists. During the Zhenguan era of the Tang, there was a man named Shen Hui. Due to his covetous heart, he accepted bribes from the people, and when the matter was exposed, he was exiled to Zhulan. Day and night, he constantly recited the *Classic of Clarity and Stillness of the Most High Lord Lao*, prostrating toward Mount Tai at dawn and dusk, saying: "I only wish to return to my hometown."

The son of the Lord of Mount Tai, the Illustrious Duke of Bingling, was traveling to the Western Marchmount for an assembly. On his return, he saw Shen Hui reciting the *Classic of Clarity and Stillness*. The Illustrious Duke spoke from the void: "This man cannot be taken." He returned to the Eastern Marchmount and told the Lord of the Peak. The Lord said: "Excellent." He ordered Shen Hui to be fetched from his secluded chamber. It was midday when he was sitting there. A crimson-robed officer appeared and said: "The Lord of the Peak summons you."

Shen Hui asked: "Which Lord of the Peak?" The officer replied: "The Lord of the Eastern Marchmount." Shen Hui was greatly startled. He quickly donned his official robes and followed the officer. When they reached the city outskirts, the officer said: "From here to Mount Tai is over three thousand *li*." Shen Hui asked: "How can I arrive?" The officer said: "We shall borrow a horse for this journey."

Shen Hui waited beneath a tree while the officer entered the temple. After a moment, he led out a small gray horse, no larger than a donkey. The officer said: "Mount the horse and close your eyes tightly." Shen Hui mounted the horse and shut his eyes. The wind rushed past like a gale. The officer said: "Open your eyes." Before him stood a city. They entered it, though the path near the city was overgrown with brambles.

They arrived at a yamen, where iron-armored guards stood on either side. The officer held the horse as Shen Hui dismounted and led him inside. A soldier asked: "Who is this?" The officer replied: "By the Lord’s decree, I bring him through the third gate." The officer said: "Sir, wait here while I announce you." The officer entered and soon returned with a herald, who said: "The Lord summons Official Shen Hui."

Shen Hui hurriedly followed and entered a magnificent hall. Pearl curtains and crimson drapes adorned the hall, which was named the Hall of Morning Radiance. The officer halted Shen Hui at the foot of the steps, where golden-armored ghost soldiers stood guard. Two azure-robed youths rolled up the curtains. Seated within was a man wearing a far-traveling cap and a blue dragon-embroidered robe, holding a cold jade tablet. Beside him stood another man in a golden moth cap, crimson garments, and an indigo jade belt, appearing to be about thirty years old.

The azure-robed youths invited Shen Hui to ascend the hall. Trembling, he could scarcely move his feet. The youths prodded him up the steps, and Shen Hui bowed. The Lord returned the bow and ordered his attendants to bring a seat for Shen Hui.

The Lord said: "When mortals commit evil, if they are not punished by men, they will be punished by ghosts. You were guilty of covetousness and thus received this sentence of exile. Yet you have recited the *Classic of Clarity and Stillness of the Most High Lord Lao* over ten thousand times in a single year. Your virtue is profound, and your reverence for me carries the mandate of the Heavenly Emperor. Thus, I shall not consign you to the path of rebirth.

If you recite this scripture and comprehend its meaning, practicing and teaching it to others, converting even one person to the Dao, your merit will increase. You may ascend not merely to the rank of celestial immortal, but to that of divine immortal; not merely to divine immortal, but to earthbound immortal; not merely to earthbound immortal, but to ghost immortal. How then could you enter the path of life and death?"

When he finished speaking, a ghost official in scarlet robes spread documents upon the table and pointed, saying: "Mu Rengui, holding a tablet, stands below the steps—he is Shen Hui’s uncle by marriage." Shen Hui turned away, not daring to look.

The Lord said: "Though you were an official governing Donghai Prefecture, you failed to govern the people with integrity. Instead, you indulged in greed, coveting bribes and killing an innocent man named Zhao."

Mu Rengui said, "I dare not."

The Lord summoned the murdered Zhao to be brought forth. From the eastern corridor, Zhao was called forward—clothed in white, hair unbound, aged about thirty.

Zhao said: "There was an old woman over seventy who died of illness in her old age. Her younger sister-in-law, coveting her family wealth, schemed against the new bride. The old woman had a patron, the prefect Mu Rengui, who received a hundred taels of gold from the younger sister-in-law. Accepting her account as truth, he condemned the new bride to death. Such is my grievance—I beseech Your Lordship to render judgment."

Rengui sought to conceal the truth, saying: "This woman indeed killed the old woman."

The Lord ordered his attendants to bring forth the Mirror of Past Deeds. When it was cast upon Rengui, it revealed that he had taken the gold and wrongfully condemned Zhao. Rengui could no longer deny it.

The Lord said: "No transgression is greater than desire, no calamity greater than greed, no crime greater than taking a life. You have committed all three offenses—how could you be pardoned?"

He commanded his attendants to seize him.

chunks.original_text: 见二鬼扶一铁床放在殿前，令仁轨脱衣。 未脱之间，其鬼以挑其腮，其腮火着，已烧半面，其身自脱，乃扶於铁床之上，以铁钉钉其身，有火焰於床下自着，苦毒之声不可见闻。 卧移时方罢，已见其体烧作焦灰。 须臾，又有一鬼吏手执一扇，乃曰：慕仁轨。 乃扇一扇，其体复故。 以铁枷枷之。 沈会乃越席而起曰：此人乃某之姑夫也。 还能救之。 王曰：冤枉争夺，损人性命，何由赦之？ 炳灵公曰：除此妇人肯罢则休，除阳问作大功德，析万圣，祷千真，除太上老君有此飞诏，先令含冤者上登云路，即证天界，方可免。 沈会曰：臣使慕仁轨改过前非，除其六欲，不生三毒，启建太上罗天大醮、天尊赦罪之科。 赵氏生天，而免仁轨苦乎？ 王曰：如此者可。 仁轨数未尽，更有五年寿。

Two ghosts dragged forth an iron bed and set it before the hall, ordering Rengui to remove his clothes. Before he could finish undressing, one ghost hooked his jaw with a prong—fire caught at once, searing half his face. His body stripped itself bare and was hoisted onto the iron bed, where iron spikes pierced his flesh. Beneath the bed, flames erupted, and his cries of agony were too terrible to witness. After lying there for some time, his body was reduced to charred ash.

Moments later, another ghostly officer appeared, holding a fan. "Mu Rengui," he called. With a single sweep of the fan, Rengui’s body was restored. They then clamped an iron cangue around his neck.

Shen Hui suddenly rose from his seat and said, "This man is my uncle by marriage. Is there any way to save him?"

The Lord replied, "He wrongfully seized property and took a life—how could he be pardoned?"

The Radiant Spirit Duke said, "Unless this woman [the sister-in-law] relents, there is no reprieve. Only by performing great meritorious deeds in the mortal realm—petitioning the myriad sages, supplicating the thousand perfected, and invoking the Most High Lord Lao’s divine edict—may the wronged be first ascended to the celestial path and attain the heavenly realms before his punishment can be lifted."

Shen Hui said, "I will ensure Mu Rengui repents of his past transgressions, relinquishes the six desires, and uproots the three poisons. I shall sponsor the Grand Offering of the Luo Heaven of the Most High and the Rite of the Heavenly Worthy’s Absolution of Sins. If Lady Zhao ascends to heaven, may Rengui be spared his suffering?"

The Lord said, "This may be permitted. Rengui’s allotted years are not yet exhausted—he has five more years of life."
